You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.

<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_init_page_sizes:
```c
static int metal_init_page_sizes(void)
{
	const int max_sizes = MAX_PAGE_SIZES - 1;
	long sizes[max_sizes];

	/* Determine system page size. */
	sizes[0] = getpagesize();
	if (sizes[0] <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to get page size\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	_metal.page_size  = sizes[0];
	_metal.page_shift = metal_log2(sizes[0]);
	metal_add_page_size(_metal.tmp_path, _metal.page_shift, 0);

#ifdef HAVE_HUGETLBFS_H
#ifndef MAP_HUGE_SHIFT
	/* System does not support multiple huge page sizes. */
	sizes[0] = gethugepagesize();
	if (sizes[0] > 0) {
		metal_add_page_size(hugetlbfs_find_path(),
				    metal_log2(sizes[0]),
				    MAP_HUGETLB);
	}
#else
	if (gethugepagesize() >= 0) {
		int i, count;

		/* System supports multiple huge page sizes. */
		count = gethugepagesizes(sizes, max_sizes);
		for (i = 0; i < count; i++) {
			int shift = metal_log2(sizes[i]);

			if ((shift & MAP_HUGE_MASK) != shift)
				continue;
			metal_add_page_size(
				hugetlbfs_find_path_for_size(sizes[i]),
				shift, (MAP_HUGETLB |
				(shift << MAP_HUGE_SHIFT)));
		}
	}
#endif
#endif

	/* Finally sort the resulting array by size. */
	qsort(_metal.page_sizes, _metal.num_page_sizes,
	      sizeof(struct metal_page_size), metal_pagesize_compare);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>

suspicious_frags:
const int max_sizes = MAX_PAGE_SIZES - 1;
	long sizes[max_sizes];
explanation: The only potential use of a compiler language extension is the array declaration using a non-constant identifier as the dimension. Declaring an automatic array with a size given by a local const int (max_sizes) is not a C90 constant expression and may be treated either as a C99 variable-length array (VLA) feature or as a compiler extension (some compilers treat a const local as non-constant and others provide extensions that accept it). All other constructs in the function are standard C or use platform APIs/macros (getpagesize, gethugepagesize, gethugepagesizes, MAP_HUGETLB, MAP_HUGE_SHIFT, qsort, sizeof, preprocessor conditionals, bitwise/shift operations, etc.) and do not constitute language extensions as documented by common compilers, so they do not need investigation for Rule 1.2.
